Easy, short, and basic, but overall quite enjoyable. 8.5/10.

Maybe a little too basic because there are a very limited number of tools, but it uses them quite well.
I really love the to-the-point gameplay. You're in a room - escape. There's no fuss, no forced interruptions, and no thing for thing's sake.
This allows for the some great flow; you can go from 1 mission to the next 10 without feeling like you've done them. The lack of overt loading screens really help this.

151139013.review:
The thought of playing Portal intimidated me. I made assumptions about the game without ever playing or seeing a gameplay video. I don’t know why I did this, there was just something in my head telling me this wasn’t the game for me. Honestly, all puzzle games intimidated me and just weren’t games I was interested in playing. Then, needing a break from Skyrim and RDR2, I added games recommended by friends and various youtubers like Razbuten and Darryl Plays Games. I took the plunge with Figment, The Room, Limbo, Inside, and Hue and for the most part enjoyed my experiences.

Now that my puzzle game anxiety had been put in check it was time to dive into Portal. I appreciate how the game eases you into the various mechanics. I found solving each chamber an absolute joy. The use of portals, cubes, and turrets is such an amazing and inventive gameplay element. I felt such a sense of accomplishment as I passed through each door. That turned to frustration with the last few chambers especially the moving platforms for death water. This feeling quickly turned to exhilaration when I finally made it to GLaDOS. The final battle was fun, and I enjoyed the story as it was revealed through each passing chamber. I found GLaDOS’ dialogue to be amusing and I couldn’t wait to take her down by the end. Navigating through the Aperture Lab and the various testing chambers was so interesting and made me want to learn more about the place and its history.

The main game is very accessible, while the advanced maps and challenge maps ratchet up the difficulty. I am so glad I gave Portal a chance and can’t wait to start Portal 2 and possibly earn myself some cake!

150370599.review:
Portal is definitely showing its age. The entire game can be beaten on a first run within 2 hours, graphics are downright ugly, puzzles are fairly simple, music is good in the 5% of the game it exists, the lacklustre story is only carried by the good dialogue, and the engine is so outdated my computer had trouble running it. 
But oh my GOD, the portal mechanic one of the best ideas in any game I have ever played!! This is something I only picked up on after finishing the game, during the advanced challenges, as these encourage you to truly understand how the system works, break it, and use it to your advantage, regardless of what was intended. Figuring out how to complete different chambers in the least amount of portals and steps by inventing clever new ways to use the tools at my disposal truly made me feel like an Aperture Science engineer. 

7.5/10

149992782.review:
Portal is a masterpiece that captured my heart from the moment I started playing. The ingenious puzzles are mind-bending and incredibly satisfying to solve. GLaDOS's witty remarks added a delightful touch to the experience,making me laugh even when faced with challenging tasks.

The game's unique concept and clever design showcase the brilliance of its creators. The feeling of accomplishment after successfully navigating each test chamber is unparalleled. Portal's short but sweet narrative,combined with the innovative portal mechanics,creates an unforgettable gaming experience.

Even years after its release, Portal stands as a testament to the timelessness of exceptional game design. If you haven't experienced the joy of portals and the thrill of "the cake is a lie",you're missing out on a gaming classic that will leave a lasting imprint on your heart. Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates creativity, humor, and a genuinely engaging gaming journey.

149957398.review:
An excellent puzzle game. The events of the game take place in the Half-Life universe, in the Aperture Science Portal Nature Research Laboratory. The player takes on the role of a girl named Chell who is being tested inside this Laboratory. Gameplay is based on solving puzzles using a portable portal device. Portal was highly praised by critics and won many awards and was so liked by players.
Among the disadvantages of the game, we can note the same levels, which sometimes makes it difficult to find the right path, as well as the weak voice acting of GLaDOS - the main antagonist of the game.
However, I definitely recommend the game, my rating is 8/10.

Відмінна гра у жанрі головоломки. Події гри розгортаються у Всесвіті Half-Life, в Лабораторії дослідження природи порталів "Aperture Science". Гравець виступає у ролі дівчини на ім'я Челл, яка проходить випробування всередині цієї Лабораторії. Ігровий процес заснований на вирішенні головоломок за допомогою переносного портального пристрою. Portal була високо оцінена критиками і отримала безліч нагород і так дуже сподобалася гравцям.
З мінусів гри можна відзначити однакові рівні, через що часом буває складно знайти правильний шлях, а також слабку озвучку GLaDOS - головного антогоніста гри.
Проте гру однозначно рекомендую, моя оцінка 8/10.

Don't let my time playing deceive you.....I have played all the way through Portal. it was a while back when I did, so I booted it up for an hour to go back and see how it still plays (since Steam didn't show any time played anymore).

Lately I have been playing Portal 2 for the first time...which is a good game. But let me put it this way:

Portal : Portal 2 :: Perfect street tacos : Taco Bell

Portal was...is...and will always be an amazing experience. Portal 2 will always be...Portal 2. So if you want to only get one...get this one. If you want to get Portal 2, get this one too. If you are a Narbacular Drop player...get this one. Do you love Half-Life? Get this one.

Portal does not dissapoint.

149611992.review:
I never reviewed Portal despite it being the game that made me install Steam.
Does Portal even need to be reviewed in 2023 ?
I can say the game is well worth its reputation. It is simple and straightforward : here is how the gun works, now get out of the room.
But puzzles get increasingly complex, requiring both thinking and skill. Finishing a room is always satisfying.
GLaDOS' framing narration is simply amazing, setting the world as this clinical precise environment, where something definitely feels off. And the more you progress, the more it feels that something is WRONG.
The final level is a game in itself, making you use every trick you've learned and dramatically concluding the story.
It is well worth playing even now, the game hasn't aged a day.

148820139.review:
I love this game, I replay it once every couple of years, it's short and sweet, and thanks to my bad memory, the puzzles are surprisingly challenging, just like how i don't remember them.

A full play through could take about 30 minutes to an hour or two.
and i decided it was about time I go for the 100% achievement run by finally beating the advanced challenges.... bad idea.

I played a full play through in about 30 minutes and went for the challenges.

Least amount of time was easy, i just had to do a couple speed-run strats and i knocked them out instantly, least portals was relatively the same thing, even though i had to do a couple chambers a few times before i got the puzzle.

But.... least amount of steps.. that was different...
least amount of steps was my hell, any slight movement or jump would count, I've spent hours just trying to beat the first challenge to no avail.. I had to give up on beating the first least amount of step level.
I started focusing on the longer maps, maps i could exploit and cheese through with my speed running knowledge and strats (i googled them). 
after clearing through every map, I went back to face my original foe, the first map of least steps, Test Chamber 13,
and after hours of precise jumping and saving every time i landed right, I have finally gotten my ribbon, 100% achievements on one of my favorite games.

Damn the was the best ~3 hour playthrough I've had, why did I put this game in the backburner for so long.

I played this game on a controller (I know, weird) and it takes getting used to at first, maybe at Test 02 or more that I've felt comfortable with it. For the graphics, I'm honestly expecting worse, since this came out in 2007 but it looks fine and doesn't deduct from the experience.

The [b]portal gun[/b] is an excellent tool and you have to wrap your brain on it at first and to how to utilize it on the Test stages. The use of physics on puzzles, specifically momentum is great.

GLaDOS is a unique antagonist, who cheers you at first but with it's monotonous and sarcastic remarks irks you the wrong way. This "test" looks to be not all jolly and safe, as you discover this hidden areas that cry for help or express love to the cube.

And the ending song, "Still Alive", just left me smiling ear to ear all throughout it. A great sendoff for a great experience, looking forward to Portal 2.

148476305.review:
Portal, a puzzle-platformer game is an absolute masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on the world of video gaming. From its innovative gameplay to its darkly humorous narrative, Portal offers an experience that's both intellectually stimulating and highly entertaining.

The core gameplay mechanic of Portal revolves around the use of a device known as the "Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device" or simply the "portal gun." With this device, players can create two interconnected portals on walls, floors, and ceilings. This simple yet brilliantly executed concept allows for a wide range of mind-bending puzzles that challenge your spatial reasoning and problem-solving skills. The puzzles become progressively more complex as you advance through the game, which keeps you engaged and motivated to solve each one.

What sets Portal apart from other puzzle games is its witty and darkly comedic narrative. You play as Chell, a silent protagonist, who awakens in the Aperture Science research facility and is guided by GLaDOS, a malevolent AI with a penchant for sarcasm. GLaDOS's humorous and increasingly sinister commentary adds a unique layer of personality to the game. Her lines have become iconic, and players will remember them long after finishing the game.

The pacing of Portal is impeccable. The game is relatively short, but it's tightly packed with memorable moments, challenging puzzles, and unexpected twists. It never outstays its welcome, leaving players craving more rather than feeling fatigued.

The minimalist visual design of Portal is both functional and aesthetically pleasing. The sterile, clinical look of the Aperture Science facility juxtaposes beautifully with the colorful, otherworldly portals themselves. This contrast not only serves the gameplay but also enhances the immersion in the game's unique atmosphere.

Portal's soundtrack is another standout element. The ambient, electronic music perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, providing an eerie and memorable backdrop to your puzzle-solving adventures.

Overall, Portal is a game that has rightly earned its place in the gaming hall of fame. Its innovative gameplay, dark humor, and clever level design make it a must-play for anyone interested in puzzle games or gaming in general. Even years after its release, Portal continues to be a beloved classic, and its influence can be seen in countless other games that followed. If you haven't had the pleasure of experiencing Portal yet, do yourself a favor and dive into this mind-bending and thoroughly enjoyable adventure.

Overall score: 8

148360809.review:
There's not really much I can say here about a 16 year old critically acclaimed game that hasn't already been said, except that all of that critical acclaim is well-earned in my opinion; this is a *very* unique twist on the basic concept of a first-person shooter from a time in which that genre was over-saturated, and in which mainstream games were generally less experimental than today. In a sense, we can probably chalk up a lot of creative modern experiments in gameplay in today's triple A and indie titles alike to the legacy of Portal, which really showed how familiar game genres can be turned into something completely new, as well as introducing the world to new ways of using simulated physics for mind-bending puzzles that are equal parts intuitive and alien.

 One thing to realize going into Portal however, this game can be *far* more difficult at times than you might expect. It's gameplay focus on physics puzzles rather than combat may lead some to mistakenly assume that this is a "casual" title that's more about idle fun than challenge, but that could not be further from the truth. There will be some points later on where this game will make you never want to see another downward > forward momentum puzzle for as long as you live. The main game is short, but in my opinion the difficulty gets high enough in the back half that I wouldn't expect to breeze through it especially quickly as a first-time player unless maybe simulated wormhole physics just clicks with you unusually well (and even if you do fall into that latter demographic, there are more difficult bonus and challenge maps that you can attempt as well). If you're someone who gets easily frustrated with finicky and time-sensitive puzzles, I'd suggest caution with Portal. Luckily, the quick save system is *extremely* generous, so you can essentially just "save scum" your way through the most complicated and unforgiving test chambers if all else fails. In any event, Portal rewards perseverance, and practice will make the surreal physics more familiar with time. 

 Also, while there isn't really any combat in the traditional sense (without going into spoilers, yes, there *are* enemies, of a sort, but the things you have to do to defeat them aren't exactly what I'd call "fighting"), it *is* possible to die at many points, and at some points you will probably end up dying *a lot* before you get things just right (again, due to the generosity with saves, dying isn't particularly punished, though).

For any Half-Life fans out there; yes, this game does take place in the same universe, although this doesn't really become readily apparent until the very end apart from a couple of small easter eggs that the observant might pick up on. Familiarity with Half-Life is absolutely not essential, though.

 In conclusion, this is a game that still holds up very well more than a decade and a half later, and which I'd highly recommend, especially if recent games like Tears of the Kingdom have gotten you interested in physics puzzles. 

 Oh yeah, and the cake is a lie.

148023742.review:
LUCKILY… STILL ALIVE

BEFORE WE BEGIN:
The game was tested in the Still Alive version, 100% completed and the platinum trophy has been obtained.

A WILD PORTAL APPEARS!:
Portal, as a typical Valve title, features impeccable level design and attention to detail right from the start. From the first minutes of play, everything is structured to create an exponential learning curve; initially the player will find himself inside a closed cell as Chell, a young girl who has been hired to test some new Aperture Science technology. Apparently, the capsule in which Chell lingers would appear to have no way out, but after a few seconds, thanks to the appearance of a portal, the player will be free to begin testing the various chambers of the Aperture facility. From there on, the player will be faced with several tests, and when he or she has mastered the blue portal, he or she will also unlock the orange one, kicking off the full potential of the game.

A NEW CUBY FRIEND:
As can be inferred from the name of the game or the introduction of the review, it is all about using portals, mainly two, one blue and one orange. These portals do not have different characteristics, but are actually unlocked at different times so that the player can figure out how to use one at a time. Several other mechanics are present, which in the same way as the portals are explained right from the start, namely the use of cubes to press buttons; obviously it is very intuitive as a mechanic, but combined with the use of portals to reach tricky buttons makes it more fun and complicated. Other mechanics rely on dodging and destroying deadly turrets, or repelling energy orbs in order to activate passages. Plot-wise, the first chapter does not hold a candle to the second, with a rather simple story with few narrative twists.


HEY, THAT’S ME!:
Graphically Portal awakens perfectly to a game of its era; moreover, due to its simplicity the game becomes almost immortal. Obviously, the aesthetics of the logos and the use of colors in the right situations are excellently done.

HEARING THE RADIO:
From an audio standpoint, there is not much to discuss; the use of sound effects to make clear the use of the various game objects and their interaction with the environment is excellent. 

ACHIEVEMENTS:
The achievements in this title are fairly simple and quick to complete. The Still Alive version of Portal provides several extra levels to tackle and two challenges in the campaign that are rather tough, namely finishing the game without ever being hit by turrets and finishing it by going only through orange portals. The latter is an obvious easter egg to the Valve’s Orange Box collection and provides a more thoughtful approach to the game's puzzles.

BUT WHY 9?

PROS - CONS:
All in all, the original Portal does not have much to discuss; all the pros have already been mentioned in the parts above; of negative points, however, I personally struggle to find any, as it really is a near-perfect game. Small appreciable detail in both Portal is the Commentary mode, where the developers explain their approach in the making of this title, useful for young programmers or more commonly for curious players.

RATING
Gameplay: 10
Music: 7
Story: 8
Puzzles: 10
_

147888839.review:
Portal - A Mind-Bending Puzzler and Instant Classic

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Portal, developed by Valve Corporation, is a game that has left an indelible mark on the world of gaming. It's a masterpiece that combines ingenious puzzle design with a darkly humorous narrative, resulting in an unforgettable gaming experience that defies conventions and continues to captivate players even years after its release.

Unique Gameplay Concept (5/5):
Portal introduces players to the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, a tool that allows them to create interdimensional portals. This groundbreaking gameplay mechanic is the core of the game and presents a series of mind-bending puzzles that challenge spatial perception and critical thinking. The sheer brilliance of Portal's puzzle design cannot be overstated.

Narrative Excellence (5/5):
While Portal's gameplay is extraordinary, its narrative is equally exceptional. The darkly comedic AI, GLaDOS, guides players through the game, offering a sharp and witty commentary that adds depth to the experience. The subtle storytelling and unexpected twists keep players engaged from start to finish.

Compact and Cohesive (5/5):
Portal is a model of efficient game design. It's a relatively short game that manages to deliver a perfectly paced and tightly woven experience. Every puzzle, every line of dialogue, and every moment contributes to the overall narrative and gameplay, making it a satisfying and cohesive journey.

Innovative First-Person Puzzler (5/5):
Portal was groundbreaking not just for its puzzles but also for its approach to first-person gameplay. It demonstrated that the first-person perspective could be used for more than just shooting, paving the way for a new genre of puzzle-based first-person games.

Minimalist Aesthetic (4/5):
Portal's minimalist aesthetic suits the game's narrative and atmosphere perfectly. The sterile test chambers and the iconic Portal gun's blue and orange portals create a visual identity that is instantly recognizable and memorable.

Enduring Legacy (5/5):
Portal's influence on the gaming industry is immeasurable. It has inspired countless puzzle games, first-person experiences, and narratives that value player agency and storytelling. The character of GLaDOS remains an iconic figure in gaming culture.

Short Duration (4/5):
While Portal's brevity contributes to its tight design, some players may wish for a longer experience. However, the concise nature of the game ensures that it can be enjoyed in a single sitting or revisited multiple times.

In conclusion, Portal is a shining example of innovation, narrative excellence, and exceptional puzzle design. It is a game that stands the test of time and continues to be celebrated as one of the greatest achievements in gaming history. Its unique gameplay, memorable characters, and darkly comedic narrative combine to create an experience that is nothing short of extraordinary. Portal's impact on gaming is immeasurable, and it remains a must-play title for anyone seeking a brilliant and mind-bending gaming adventure, earning a perfect 5/5 rating for its sheer brilliance and enduring legacy.

147320142.review:
[b]A Revolutionary Puzzler That Redefines Logic and Wit[/b]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Portal, developed by Valve Corporation, stands as a monumental achievement in gaming, defying conventional norms and catapulting players into a mind-bending puzzle adventure. With its innovative mechanics, captivating narrative, and witty humor, Portal is a genre-defining experience that has left an indelible mark on the gaming world.

[h1]Groundbreaking Gameplay Mechanics[/h1]
At the core of Portal's brilliance are its gameplay mechanics, introducing players to the mind-bending concept of creating and traversing portals. The ability to manipulate space and physics through these portals adds an unprecedented layer of depth to the puzzle-solving experience. The simplicity of the mechanics belies the complexity of the challenges, keeping players engaged and intellectually stimulated throughout their journey.

[h1]Intelligently Designed Puzzles[/h1]
Portal's puzzles are a testament to meticulous design and thoughtful planning. Each puzzle presents a unique challenge, encouraging players to experiment with the portal gun and exploit the game's mechanics creatively. The gradual increase in difficulty strikes a perfect balance, ensuring that players feel a sense of achievement with each solved puzzle.

[h1]Compelling Narrative and Humor[/h1]
Portal weaves a compelling narrative through its protagonist, Chell, and the omnipresent and enigmatic AI, GLaDOS. The darkly humorous and at times unsettling dialogues add an intriguing layer to the gameplay. The witty banter and dry humor often provide a welcome respite from the challenging puzzles, creating a well-rounded gaming experience.

[h1]Aesthetically Pleasing and Immersive[/h1]
The sterile, clinical environments of the Aperture Science Enrichment Center, juxtaposed with the vibrant and futuristic aesthetics of the portal technology, make for a visually striking setting. The attention to detail in both design and sound immerses players in the world of Portal, enhancing the overall experience.

[h1]Short and Sweet[/h1]
Portal's concise gameplay duration is a strength, as it ensures the experience remains tight, focused, and leaves players craving more. The succinct storyline and well-paced progression prevent any sense of monotony or unnecessary padding, providing a satisfying and memorable gaming experience.

[h1]Cult Classic and Lasting Impact[/h1]
Portal has left an enduring legacy in the gaming community. Its unique mechanics, compelling narrative, and iconic lines ("The cake is a lie") have become a part of gaming culture, influencing subsequent titles and cementing its status as a cult classic.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Portal is a masterclass in game design, seamlessly blending innovative mechanics, stimulating puzzles, witty narrative, and captivating aesthetics. Its influence on the gaming industry is immeasurable, and its enduring popularity among players stands as a testament to its exceptional quality. Portal is not just a game; it's an experience that leaves players yearning for more innovative adventures in the world of interactive entertainment.

147204226.review: To be honest, I've never been really good at puzzle games: I'd quit after reaching a puzzle I couldn't solve. This game was different. With the coolest game mechanic to mess with, a subtle story that gradually grows to become more climactic, intuitive puzzles of increasing difficulty, and the god-tier humor of GLaDOS, I refused to let myself quit at any puzzle, even level eighteen. It's also no surprise why this game is so good: just look at the history of Valve's game testing on Portal; the game commentaries you can go through after your first walkthrough will show their dedication. Violence wise, this game is minimal when it comes to what you do to your enemies. As for damage done against you, the machine guns shot by the turrets can be quite loud and jarring to some. These bullets will leave marks on the walls and glass. If you get shot, blood splatters will appear behind you on a wall as though you've been shot through, but it will only be like an added texture. You can actually get shot an infinite amount of times; death comes when you have been shot at for a decent amount of time (probably about 3 seconds maybe). No blood sprays are present. If you're fine with occasional blood appearing up on walls (it's more of a splot (no blood dripping down the walls; it's a static texture)) and the loud sound of machine gun fire, get it. Only those two things could make it more mature. I recommend this game to people 12 years of age and older.

147045408.review:
Portal Review

For all its heady delights, Portal is a short-lived feast and can be reasonably completed in as little as five hours. To help draw things out a bit, Valve has included six advanced chambers, all of which are existing test chambers tweaked to present a tougher challenge. You can also take on challenge maps and attempt to complete the test chambers with the least number of portals, the least steps, or in the least time. Ever since it was originally released more than six months ago, there has been ample time for the online community to produce a bevy of maps that, though varying in quality, are freely available for any test-chamber-hungry portaler to download. Its Orange Box roots mean that Portal also comes equipped with in-game achievements that can serve to extend its longevity. Nevertheless, the odds are that it'll be over a bit too quickly for your liking.

If portal technology is the meat of the game, then GLaDOS is the perfectly paired wine. The omnipresent voice that guides you through the test chambers, GLaDOS initially reveals a dry, almost unintentional sense of humor in the first few test chambers. As you progress, her humor begins to show signs of self-awareness, eventually blossoming into something too hilarious and too well-deployed to spoil here. Suffice it to say, it is one of the chief pleasures of Portal and features some of the best writing in video game history.

Short as it may be, Portal is a fantastic game that should be played by anyone interested in unique, well-crafted gameplay and a witty, whip-smart script. The stand-alone retail release comes with the same price point as the downloadable Steam release, which is about the cost of a night out at the movies. Portal may not last much longer than some feature films, but pound for pound it remains one of the best games on store shelves. This game is still alive!

146874273.review: Portal 1 is hands down one of the best games ever made by Valve. The game's unique blend of first-person gameplay and puzzle-solving is simply unmatched. The game's premise, in which you play a test subject in a mysterious Aperture Science facility, is both intriguing and engaging. The game's writing and voice acting are also top-notch, with hilarious and memorable lines from the game's robot antagonist, GLaDOS. Portal 1's use of the portal gun, which allows the player to create portals and teleport themselves and objects around the environment, is a stroke of genius in game design. The puzzles in the game are challenging but never frustrating, and the game's pacing is perfect. Overall, Portal 1 is a masterpiece of game design that will always stand the test of time.

146822156.review:
Portal es un ejemplo excepcional de cómo un juego puede combinar una narrativa intrigante, rompecabezas ingeniosos y un carácter único para crear una experiencia verdaderamente memorable en el mundo de los videojuegos.

La premisa de Portal es simple pero intrigante: te despiertas en un laboratorio de pruebas aparentemente abandonado y te encuentras equipado con un dispositivo de portal que puede crear portales en superficies específicas. Esta herramienta te permite resolver una serie de rompecabezas ingeniosos y desafiantes mientras exploras el enigmático Aperture Science Enrichment Center.

Una de las fortalezas más notables de Portal es su narrativa y su personaje principal, GLaDOS. A medida que avanzas en el juego, GLaDOS te guía (o engaña) con un sentido del humor sutil y retorcido que se ha convertido en un elemento icónico de la serie. La forma en que la historia se desarrolla gradualmente y cómo aprendes más sobre el mundo del juego a través de las interacciones con GLaDOS es brillante y cautivante.

Los rompecabezas de Portal son ingeniosos y desafiantes sin ser frustrantes. El juego te lleva gradualmente a través de conceptos y mecánicas cada vez más complejos, lo que te permite aprender y dominar las habilidades del dispositivo de portal de manera orgánica. Cada rompecabezas se siente como un logro cuando lo resuelves, y la sensación de logro es recompensada con la satisfacción de avanzar en la narrativa.

El diseño visual minimalista de Portal es efectivo y memorable. Los entornos estériles y las pruebas de laboratorio contrastan con la personalidad brillante y oscura de GLaDOS, creando un ambiente que se siente único en el mundo de los videojuegos.

La música en Portal, incluida la icónica canción "Still Alive", añade otra capa de carácter y profundidad al juego. La canción, interpretada por GLaDOS, se ha convertido en un himno para los fanáticos del juego.

COMPRALOOOOO

146682347.review:
Uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado. Sinceramente es un juego muy auto explicativo, va de portales como el nombre lo indica, no tienes por que saber más, los niveles van a estar diseñados para hacerte pensar en como usar la mecánica principal; es muy intuitivo y divertido, nunca llegaras a frustrarte (al menos no en los niveles normales).

Para los más tryhards y que quieran un reto aún mayor están los desafiantes "niveles de bonificación" los cuales se dividen en dos, salas avanzadas y retos, las salas avanzadas modificaran los últimos 6 niveles para hacerlos más difíciles teniendo que pensar más para lograr pasarlos; los retos son algo muy distinto, al igual que las salas avanzadas, los retos usan los últimos 6 niveles, pero ahora poniéndote metas, siendo estas el uso de menos portales, menos tiempo y la más difícil, menos pasos. Estos últimos desafíos realmente aumentaran de forma exponencial la experiencia de Portal, aunque después de ese arduo recorrido es bastante satisfactorio poder romper las metas que el juego te coloca.

Uno de los mejores juegos de Steam a un precio muy barato, suponiendo un reto para toda clase de jugdores.

A nice simple and fun introductory puzzle game

Though it is pretty short without much replay value (unless your a speed runner) as i beat the game my first time around within 90 minutes (including credits and bathroom breaks)

But it was a high quality 90 minutes, and a great introductory game if you want to get into the puzzle genre as this game set the winning puzzle game formula on easing the player into the mechanics

if you want to try it out and your patient, wait for it to go on sale, it consistently goes to $1, then get the game in a bundle along with portal 2, they will cost less then $2 combined making them great value for gamers on a budget

The worse thing i can say about the game is it's about an 8GB download for any old potato computers, but that's a pretty small download for most people

146606930.review:
portal is a pretty good game which introduced some very interesting mechanics. the main campaign is a nice bite size experience though the puzzles were nothing to complex. i am a little less enthusiastic on the bonus maps for they were all reused campaign maps and no unique maps, the advanced maps were fun little challenges that made the existing maps harder to achieve which i really liked. now the challenge maps is where the mechanics of the game fail for me, there is no addition to the  structure of the map only limitations on what you can do. the least portals is  the only fun limitation because it causes you to think of the map in a new way. the speed-run category makes you use controls that were not developed for speed-running and is very frustrating clears. the least steps category fundamentally do not work as sometimes the player steps twice instead of once causing a lot of frustration. 

i know most of this review seems like i don't like the game but i do the game is only being held back by the fact that it was made in 2007, overall a fairly good game and i am looking forward to how portal 2 will improve the strong foundation. 6.8/10

146596809.review: What is there to say about Portal that hasn't already been said? What could I possibly write here that most people probably don't already know? There are plenty of reasons why Portal 1 and Portal 2 are thousands of people's favourite games. The writing of portal is witty and hilarious while somehow simultaneously being unsettling and foreboding, the puzzles are engaging yet still intuitive and fair, the atmosphere is second only to that of Portal 2 (by a slim margin), and above all else it's just fun. If there's one thing you should know about this game, it's that it's fun, which is what's important. 10/10.

146587231.review: One of the best experiences in gaming I've had.

146575096.review:
This is my first Steam review. I am very new to REAL PC gaming, (lived off of everything Nintendo since 2010, on my school computers I've played flash games) and wanted to play a classic that I remember seeing years ago. I am so glad I did. I never used to think of myself as a puzzle game enjoyer as I have a short fuse and tend to rage quit. However, there is something so fun yet calming in the game play that allowed me to pause at moments within the game and figure everything out myself. This is actually the first puzzle game I've completed entirely by myself, ever. I feel like in this game you can really focus on the puzzles as well, coming from Nintendo games such as the Legend of Zelda, with temples and stuff, I often just looked up all the answers because I just wanted to get back to destroying pots and whatever. This game is great at doing what it's meant to, and MORE! Such as...
the little bits of story. Truly, it's smaller details but it did a good job at freaking me out at 2am while I was playing it. The creepiness really leaves an impression. Also, yeah, I lost track of time playing this. I NEVER thought I'd say that about a puzzle game. 

This was a wonderful nostalgia filled game for me and I look forward to playing it again and getting all of the achievements! What a great start to my PC gaming journey!

146526268.review:
Al igual que otros juegos de Valve como Half Life o Team Fortress 2, Portal ha envejecido increíblemente bien con el paso del tiempo y demuestra ser una joya dentro de su catálogo.

En este caso, Portal se trata de un juego de puzzles que se controla como un shooter en primera persona y que se caracteriza por ser original, tener unas mecánicas muy sólidas y una curva de dificultad muy buena, ya que progresivamente los puzzles se irán volviendo más difíciles y te exigirán que recuerdes lo que el juego te ha ido enseñando hasta ese momento.

Lo que hace especial a Portal es que no solo tiene un gameplay muy bueno, sino que, además, a la que llegas a la mitad del juego te vas dando cuenta de que tiene una historia de trasfondo llena de misterios que te atrapa y te mantiene intrigado hasta que llegas al final.

La única pega que le veo a Portal es que es muy corto y ofrece poco contenido extra que te incite a rejugarlo, pero aún así me parece un juego excelente y que, además, si esperas a comprarlo de oferta te sale por menos de 1€, así que al final la duración del juego acaba compensando bastante.

¡Le doy un 9/10!

Portal no es un juego de puzzles, portal en sí mismo es el puzzle.
